page.title: 13The Harringworth Viaduct 1
page.content:
The most distinctive feature of the landscape in this area of South-east Rutland is the railway viaduct spanning the River Welland between Seaton ans Harringworth. Completed in 1878, this viaduct is still a masterpiece of industrial architecture. It is still used by goods trains, and very occasionally passenger trains are diverted across it.
The Viaduct is three-quarters of a mile long, with 82 arches, each with a span of 40 feet and a height of almost 60 feet. It contains 20 million bricks, 20 thousand cubic yards of concrete and 90 thousand cubic yards of stone. If the bricks were used to pave a pathway 5 feet 3 inches wide, it would stretch from London to York.
